page.title: 04ECOLOGY OF FRILSHAM (2)
page.content: As this part of Berkshire is quiet and relatively unspoiled there is{plant and{animal life}in abundance. Many foxes and badgers are here. Colonies of rabbits are now breeding rapidly again resistant to myxymatosis. Also there are many small animals such as moles and weasels. Deer too, like rabbits damage farm crops. There are many birds in the field hedges. Herons can be seen on the Pang and the nightingale can still be heard. The north of Frilsham is bounded by the M4 motorway and the banks on each side of it are now a new area of{conservation. Up above birds such as hawks and plovers ignore the traffic and breed here.{Rare flowers}such as cowslips grow here where men do not tread. There is much{deciduous woodland.}Fine beech trees were planted in the 19th century for timber as well as beauty.
